translation.en: [man] Chill out.

translation.en: but you'd be surprised what there is on YouTube.

I need to do something that's obviously completely unnatural.

translation.en: No dogs glow, so if I make a dog that glows,

-[beeping] -[theme music plays]
[man 1] We're on the verge of a technological breakthrough
that could change the future of mankind.
[man 2] Most people have no idea how rapidly things are changing.
translation.ko: 얼마나 급격히 변화 중인지 대부분 사람은 모르죠

translation.en: It can alter the DNA in any cell in any organism,

translation.en: including animal and plant cells, even human cells.

translation.en: So, here I am holding this little tube, and it looks so simple,

translation.en: We are about to unfold for you an adventure in the world of science,

translation.en: the science that deals with the nature of living things.
Our story is about you and me.
The story is the same for all living things.
Animals, plants,
even the lowliest creature.
Using physical and chemical clues,

translation.en: and what we will be like.

[man] It'd be a major change in our ability to transform genes.

For years we debated it,

Now we can do it.
Working with evolution a lot does make you think about...

translation.en: "Why are we here?"

[Esvelt] We think it's tragic when evolution makes something beautiful...

translation.en: and then it goes away forever.
But evolution doesn't care.
Evolution is always interested in what can be better.
It does not care about suffering.
The interesting question in my mind is to what extent we should defy evolution
in service to our morality.
What life has explored in all of this incredible diversity
translation.ko: 이 놀라운 다양성 속에서 생명이 탐구한 것은

translation.en: is still the tiniest of tiny fractions of what is actually possible.

translation.en: What's different now

translation.ko: 이 방에 있는 모든 종의 DNA를 읽을 수 있단 거죠

translation.en: We're learning how to intervene

It's amazing the sorts of things that we could do with this.
translation.ko: 이걸로 할 수 있는 일들은 정말 놀랍죠

translation.en: But...
the question is...
should we, and who gets a say?
[man] A genome is DNA that consists of a code

translation.ko: 암호는 네 종류의 글자죠 A, C, G, T

translation.en: In the early 2000s, there was that sort of catalytic event
translation.ko: 2000년대 초반에 "유전학자 프레스턴 에스텝 박사" 시발점이 있었습니다

translation.en: when we created the first draft sequence of the human genome.
translation.ko: 인간 유전체 염기 서열의 초안을 만든 거죠

translation.en: [Regis Philbin] ...hoping it's gonna be the best year all of us have ever had.
translation.ko: 우리 모두에게 역대 최고의 해가 될 것 같군요

translation.en: [Bill Clinton] Today, we are learning the language in which God created life.
translation.ko: 오늘날, 우리는 신이 생명을 만든 언어를 배우고 있습니다

translation.en: This is the most important, most wondrous map

translation.en: ever produced by humankind.
[Estep] Gathering together all that information about the human genome

And having that parts list allows us to understand
translation.ko: 그리고 그 부품표를 통해 알게 됐죠

translation.en: how that code makes people,
how it is broken in people with diseases.
This piece of paper has 6,400 letters, front and back.
Given the size of the genome,
it would take one million
of these pieces of paper, printed front and back,
to print out the entire genome.
One letter change in the 6.4 billion bases
can cause a serious disease.

translation.en: [reporter 1] One of the most significant developments
in this field is the newly discovered ability to modify
the very genes in our DNA.
The technique is known by the acronym CRISPR.
CRISPR is a technique that allows scientists to go into the DNA
of a plant or an animal, or even a human being,
and remove or replace a small part of that organism's genetic code.
translation.ko: 생물 유전 암호 속 작은 부분을 제거하거나 교체할 수 있죠

translation.en: -How big of a breakthrough is this? -Wow!
The potential of what can be done here.
[reporter 2] CRISPR has generated immense excitement.

translation.ko: 유전 암호를 아주 정확히 자르고 붙일 수 있죠

translation.en: [reporter 3] A professor at the University of California, Berkeley,
Jennifer Doudna, who helped develop this breakthrough...
translation.ko: 제니퍼 다우드나 교수가 이 혁신을 도왔으며...

translation.en: [reporter 4] What is CRISPR-Cas9?

fundamental change in the technology for gene editing.
translation.ko: "크리스퍼 공동 발견자 제니퍼 다우드나" 유전자 편집 기술은 근본적인 변화를 맞았습니다

translation.en: It really works like a molecular scalpel,

We can control where it makes a change in a DNA sequence.

translation.en: Chemical cleavers in the protein
swing into position and cut the DNA

Could it cure virtually any disease?
translation.ko: 실제로 모든 질병을 치료할 수 있나요?

translation.en: -Any disease that has a genetic basis. -That's incredible.

translation.en: It's raised a lot of concerns,
-ethical concerns... -Yeah.
...about playing God.
-You are changing something forever. -Yeah.

translation.en: What is it that we have to turn on and off in our genomes

We are learning how to copy, edit, paste DNA,
translation.ko: 우리는 DNA를 복사하고 편집하고 붙여넣는 법을 배우고 있습니다

translation.en: the same thing you will do in a word processor.

translation.en: That means rewriting the book of life.
What we see here is a chicken embryo

It has a head. It has limbs.
This experiment entailed just adding one factor, one gene,
